intro: Reseda fluminensis, commonly known as the Brazilian mallow, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, pink or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in wetlands and marshy areas, thriving in moist, sandy soils. Its leaves are palmate, with five to seven lobes, and it produces capsule fruits that contain numerous seeds. Reseda fluminensis is often used in ornamental gardening due to its attractive appearance and adaptability to wet environments.
